summary: On May 10, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of South Dakota entered a final judgment against a defendant in a civil injunctive action brought by the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Sturgis, South Dakota, alleges that Ronda Halvorson violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and the administrative adjudication provision of Section 15(b)(1) thereunder. The complaint alleges that the federal district court entered final judgments in favor of the defendant, finding that the FTCA's preemption provision was inconsistent with the federal statute of repose. The court also found that the SEC's administrative proceeding provisions did not apply to all of the defendants.  In a parallel action, on May 9, 2017, the Honorable Judge Vivian M. Welshhans issued an order requiring defendants to submit written objections to the Commission's proposed findings and recommendations to the court. The order also requires defendants to show cause and effect, including whether they are reasonable and reasonable, that they are subject to the preemption provisions of the federal securities laws.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of final judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the charged provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act"), and orders defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest and a civil penalty of $1,000,000. The settlement is subject to court approval.  On May 17, 2016, the court granted a request for a temporary restraining order and ordered the SEC to conduct an administrative proceeding against the defendants in the case.  A hearing is scheduled for June 21, 2018.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-2331, July 10, 2017.  Separately, the SEC filed a complaint in federal district courts in Arizona, Utah, Arizona, and New Jersey, alleging that the Commission violated Section 15 of the Exchange Act and Rule 15b2-14. The SEC is seeking a permanent injunction against future violations of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of this federal securities law, as well as preliminary and permanent injunctions against further violations of Section 16(a)(2) and (3) of these provisions. The Commission's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by Michael R. Kasper and supervised by Eric R. Werner of the Chicago Regional Office. The litigation will be led by
